text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: JOHN A MACMURCHY

Present Address: SEMANS

Pioneer Address: 1915 Streetburg, 1906 Lornhill

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1915

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? 
   How often did you usually visit neighbors?
   Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?
   Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

2. What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? 
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?
   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)
   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

3. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

4. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? 
   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

5. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.
   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.
   Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

NO. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How often did you visit? At least 50% of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? We traveled in circumstances.

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Nearly each day.

4. Were you often invited to other homes? Or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and around the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "tea porridge" used, or was some other expression common?) You will stop for dinner.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Refreshments.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Not often.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings; giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you knew, were there many parties, whilst driving or dances in homes? Describe.

We did not dance or play cards so we only went to parties playing games.

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn, visiting one home to another at definite times, every two weeks once a month, etc.?
2. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Christmas tree, dances in grounds; an old boy or other social eventing no dances until after 1921

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Considerable amount

9. When was your first community hall built? In December 1915

What material was it made of? Frame How large was it? 30 x 90

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Private

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) We used the school just the same,

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Mostly

How were babies and small children provided for? They were packed on the backs of seats which were tucked against the wall

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? A stable was built on the school grounds

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Some, but the trustees did not allow dancing in the school

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some did not accept card playing so there were no public gatherings for some years
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities (include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc.). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? In what material was it made? How large was it? How was it built? Who built it? The community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? Did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? How were tables and small children provided for? How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Was there card playing for prizes? What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disapproval between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?  
   *I did not notice any*

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?  
   Sometimes  
   Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.  
   *I never joined in one so don't know much about them*

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.  
   In the early days my favorite game was charades for larger parties

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?  
   Outside of Church activities I do not know of any Organization  
   Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?  
   Yes  
   Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.  
   *I do not know much of this organization*  
   Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?  
   How many women belonged?  
   How often did it meet?  
   What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?  
   *Not until the 30's*  
   When was it organized?  
   Approximately how many women belonged to it?  
   Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality or "visiting" do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially.

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, as fairs and social life because of changes in visiting or social life because of migration.

In the early days my favorite game was

Character for larger parties

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaires for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

I do not remember much about this.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Baseball, football

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was organized, its size (members), its aims and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included a church district, or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (These are spaces in the church, clubs and other organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

I do not remember much about this.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures or talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

The provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *Skating, Football (in the snow)*

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *Card games, Authors, or crokinole*

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *Everybody played when possible*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *Considerable time in the evening*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *Don't remember any*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *In July of 1905*

26. Who organized it?  
   *Community*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *for community*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *Yes*

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *Ball races, dancing on the first picnic was beside a small lake*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *We all ate together, a general lunch*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Sandwiches, pie, cake - Lemonade*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *About 2 p.m., until sundown*
22. What winter games were played outside—fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, games of Indian objects of warfare, or games in the ordinary everyday life?

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it? Community of 1905

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Ball races, bowling, the first picture was beside a small lake.

30. What arrangements were made for eating—was there a general lunch, or did families form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Handwritten, yes, cake—lemonade.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? About 2 p.m., ended around 5 p.m.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

I don't remember any features as I was only 11 years old.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Most picnics were of the same general nature.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Nowadays the only picnics held are annual school picnics, and are mostly local.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

We played football extensively the first year, then switched to baseball.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

First year hockey was started.

What year? About 1909-10

How long did it continue? Ever since.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Hockey was organized in Lemans winter 1909-10 and we had one of the best hockey teams in Saskatchewan until 1915-16 when war stopped.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

1909-10 just hockey & skating.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1911-12. Hockey, skating, curling.

2 curling ices
33. Describe any features of this parade which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe the different kinds of parades which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community parades, school or Sunday School parades, family parades, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in parades since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1911-12: Hockey, skating, curling.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1909.
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Yes.
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). We tried all days starting July 1st.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names and dates.

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Most all of them.
What kind of books and how many? Fiction, Travel, Biography, History.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? I read them all.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Not at first we couldn't afford them. Later & built up a large selection.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? An odd fashion book.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates. Not until later on.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? When school was built.
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? I do not know.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Not that I know of.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1909

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plant? 

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held (city, town, or special day, such as May 24th or July 4th)?

Was there any free library in the town at that time?

41. Are there any free libraries who have become members of the National Free Library Association?

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell us nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Most all of them.

What kind of books did they bring?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes

When was it begun? When did it close?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Not really know of
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? 
   When was it started? 1923  
   Who started it? South River  
   Is it still in existence? No  
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why? 
   It was taken over by the Lemon School District and placed in school library.  
   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books. 
   It only lasted about 2 years, was financed 50% by local people, 50% by provincial Govt. It was handled by the local drug store, but people did not continue to subscribe so it dropped out.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? 
   The Family Herald/Weekly Star

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others. 
   Contained the F.H., D.W., Star and added various farm papers.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? 
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have? 
   Only two books. I still have the books listed in #2 except Lincoln.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. 
   Not much as I borrowed all the books for several miles around, and also could read a book several times.
51. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started? 1923

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

$2.00 by local people $5.00 by personal gift

2 hours borrowed by 2 local boys, three, but people did not continue to subscribe.

52. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the family? Weekly Star

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. Not much at all. I borrowed all the books for several years around, and also would read a book several times.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Organ

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Mostly organs, one or two pianos

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. Piano in 1916 in Regina,

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. Music played a large part such as church choir and general singing also concerts, with solos duets etc.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Most of the old favorites

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. We were all Anglo-Saxon, either Canadian born or English or Scotch.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes When was it started? 1911
Who started it? Don't know How long did it continue? 1916
How many were in it? 15 Who was bandmaster? Mr. Readman
What instruments were included? All usual band instruments

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Members had uniforms and played for sports days, etc.

In 1918-19 another band was formed of which I was a member; we bought out an overseas band outfit from Col. Lang of Young, and formed a 25 piece band gradually decreased to 15. We ran to 1941 when the German took over Bandmaster was H. Hawley
MEDICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give names, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home environment in early years in the West? Describe, in detail, where there was musical concerts, parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever take up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? If so, who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where members met, uniforms worn, etc., and played for what occasions.

In 1918-19 another band was formed which was a military band but continued playing for parades.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

The band here is operated as a school feature so can only go so far. They play for different public local events also for local sport day.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I made a hobby of photography and developed and printed my own pictures but discontinued it after some years.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music an important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

The band here is operated by a school chapter.

We can only lend them for a limited period of time.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I made a hobby of photography and developed and printed my own pictures, but discontinued it after about four years.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others, such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
Oxford

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
